variant.question: An aircraft flying at FL230 is cleared by Air Traffic Control to descend to FL110. The average temperature for the descent is ISA + 15° C. The vertical distance of the descent is...
A 200 hPa pressure altitude level can vary in height. In temperate regions which of the following average flight levels is applicable?
A 700 hPa pressure level can vary in height. In temperate regions which of the following average flight levels is applicable?
A 850 hPa pressure level can vary in height. In temperate regions which of the following average flight levels is applicable?
A 500 hPa pressure level can vary in height. In temperate regions which of the following average flight levels is applicable?
A vertical spacing of 1 000 ft, is the standard required separation between two FL. Under conditions of cold air advection (ISA -15 °C), what would the true vertical separation be?

options.text: Without QNH information, it can not be determined.

variant.question: During descent, the transition level given by ATC is at FL55; true altitude is 6 000 ft; local QNH is unknown. What assumption (if any) can be made about the airmass in which the aircraft is flying?

options.text: There is insufficient information to make any assumption.
Its average temperature is the same as ISA.

variant.question: If you are flying at FL 300 in an air mass that is 15°C warmer than a standard atmosphere, what is the outside temperature likely to be?
In the ICAO standard atmosphere, which of the following alternatives indicates the correct vertical temperature distribution in the lowest 11 km?

options.text: 15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.
15.2°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.
15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 feet.
13°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 2°C per 1 000 feet.

variant.question: In the ICAO standard atmosphere, which of the following alternatives indicates the correct vertical temperature distribution in the lowest 11 km?

options.text: 15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.
13°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 2°C per 1 000 feet.
15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 feet.
15.2°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.

variant.question: In the ICAO standard atmosphere, which of the following statements indicates the correct vertical temperature distribution in the lowest 11 km?

options.text: 15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.
13°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 2°C per 1000 feet.
15°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 feet.
15.2°C at mean sea level, decreasing at 0.65°C per 100 metres.

variant.question: In mid-latitudes, between the tropopause and FL650, as altitude increases, air temperature...

options.text: varies, but generally remains relatively constant.
initially decreases rapidly then increases slowly.

variant.question: At FL180, the air temperature is -35°C. The air density at this level is:

options.text: greater than the density of the ISA atmosphere at FL180.
equal to the density of the ISA atmosphere at FL180.
less than the density of the ISA atmosphere at FL180.
unable to be determined without knowing the QNH.

variant.question: The altitude indicated on board an aircraft flying in an atmosphere where all atmosphere layers below the aircraft are warm is

options.text: the same as the real altitude.

variant.question: If atmospheric conditions exist such that the temperature deviation is ISA +10°C in the lower troposphere up to 18 000 ft, what is the actual layer thickness between FL60 and FL120?

During descent, you are passing FL55, which is also considered as being the transition level. The true altitude is 6 000 ft and local QNH is unknown. What assumption, if any, can be made about the air mass in which the aircraft is flying?

options.text: There is insufficient information to make any assumption.
Its average temperature is the same as ISA.

 The pressure at sea level is 1023 hPa.
 What is your approximate true altitude calculated using normal vertical change in temperature with increase in height?
 (Note assume 1 hPa = 27 ft)

(Note: assume 1 hPa = 27 ft)

options.text: the same as the true altitude.

variant.question: You are flying over the sea at FL 250 and measure an outside temperature of -50°C. The pressure at sea level is 1023 hPa. What is your approximate true altitude calculated using normal vertical change in temperature with increase in height?
What is the temperature deviation from the International Standard Atmosphere overhead Frankfurt at FL180?

The crew is planning a flight across Himalayas at FL390, which is above the tropopause. The QNH at the station located at 5 000 ft is 1 013 hPa. Forecasted temperature at FL390 is -48°C. What would be the clearance above the peak of 29 029 ft.

A crew planning a flight at FL390 over the Himalayas is making drift-down calculations. Given the following meteorological information, what is the approximate vertical separation above terrain with a maximum elevation of 29029 ft?
QNH measured at 5000 ft elevation: 1013 hPa 
Forecast temperature at FL390: -48° C
A temperature of 10 °C below ISA is observed at FL180. What is the vertical distance between FL60 and FL120?
A temperature of 10 °C above ISA is observed at FL180. What is the vertical distance between FL60 and FL120?

options.text: It is not possible to give a definitive answer.

variant.question: If atmospheric conditions exist such that the temperature is ISA +10°C in the lower troposphere up to 18000 ft, what is the actual layer thickness between FL 60 and FL 120?
In mid-latitudes, what happens to the air temperature as altitude increases between the tropopause and FL 650?

options.text: It varies, but generally remains relatively constant.
It varies, but generally increases rapidly.
It varies, but generally decreases slowly.
It initially decreases rapidly then increases slowly.

Over Paris at what flight level would you expect to find the tropopause according to the map?
Assuming a normal vertical temperature gradient, at what approximate altitude can we find the freezing level above Berlin?

In western Europe, an aircraft is flying directly towards the centre of a depression at an altitude of 5000 ft. If no other factors apply, which of the following statements is most likely to be correct:

options.text: The aircraft will experience drift to the right (starboard)
The aircraft will experience a direct tailwind without drift
The aircraft will experience drift to the left (port)
The aircraft will experience a direct headwind without drift

variant.question: A layer in which the temperature increases with height is:
A layer can be

options.text: stable for unsaturated air and unstable for saturated air.
unstable for unsaturated air and neutral for saturated air.
unstable for unsaturated air and conditionally unstable.
stable for saturated air and unstable for unsaturated air.

You will arrive at your destination before you have to cross the warm front.
